DIV1.P: Acted by the Queenes Maiesties Ser∣uants, at The Phaenix in Drury-Lane.
LONDON, Printed by Nicholas Okes for Richard Collins, and are to be sold at his shop in Pauls Church-yard, at the signe of the three Kings. 1633.

DIV1.HEAD: To the truely Noble, Iohn, Earle of Peterborough, Lord Mordant, Baron of Turuey.
DIV1.P:
WHere a Truth of Meritt hath a generall warrant, There Loue is but a Debt, Acknow∣ledgement a Iustice. Greatnesse cannot often claime Virtue by Inheritance; Yet in this, YOVRS appeares most Emi∣nent, for that you are not more rightly Heyre to your Fortunes, then Glory shalbe to your Memory. Sweetenesse of disposition ennobles a freedome of Birth; in BOTH, your lawfull Interest adds Honour to your owne Name, and mercy to my presumption. Your Noble allowance of These First Fruites of my leasure in the Action, embol∣dens my confidence, of your as noble constructi∣on in this Presentment: especially since my Ser∣uice must euer owe particular duty to your Fa∣uours,
by a patticular Ingagement. The Grauity of the Subiect may easily excuse the leightnesse of the Title: otherwise, I had beene a seuere Iudge a∣gainst mine owne guilt. Princes haue vouchsaf't Grace to trifles, offred from a purity of Deuotion, your Lordship may like wise please, to admit into your good opinion, with these weake endeuours, the constancy of Affection from the sincere Louer of your Deserts in Honour

DIV1.HEAD: To my Friend the Author.
DIV1.L: WIth admiration I behel'd This Whore
Adorn'd with Beauty, such as might restore
(If euer being as Thy Muse hath fam'd)
Her Giouanni, in his loue vnblam'd:
The ready Graces lent their willing ayd,
Pallas her selfe now playd the Chamber-maide
And help't to put her Dressings on: secure
Rest Thou, that Thy Name herein shull endure
To th'end of Age; and Annabella bee
Gloriously Faire, euen in her Infamie.

SP.SPEAKER: Fryar.
SP.L: DIspute no more in this, for know (young man)
These are no Schoole-points; nice Philosophy
May tolerate vnlikely arguments,
But Heauen admits no jest; wits that presum'd
On wit too much, by striuing how to proue
There was no God; with foolish grounds of Art,
Discouer'd first the neerest way to Hell;
And fild the world with deuelish Atheisme:
Such questions youth are fond; For better 'tis,
To blesse the Sunne, then reason why it shines;
Yet hee thou talk'st of, is aboue the Sun,
No more; I may not heare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Gentle Father,
To you I haue vnclasp't my burthened soule,
Empty'd the store-house of my thoughts and heart,
Made my selfe poore of secrets; haue not left
Another word vntold, which hath not spoke
All what I euer durst, or thinke, or know;
And yet is here the comfort I shall haue,
Must I not doe, what all men else may, loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Yes. you may loue faire sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Must I not praise
That beauty, which if fram'd a new, the gods
Would make a god of, if they had it there;
And kneele to it, as I doo kneele to them?

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Why foolish mad-man?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Shall a peeuish sound,
A customary forme, from man to man,
Of brother and of sister, be a barre
Twixt my perpetuall happinesse and mee?
Say that we had one father, say one wombe,
(Curse to my ioyes) gaue both vs life, and birth;
Are wee not therefore each to other bound
So much the more by Nature; by the the links
Of blood, of reason; Nay if you will hau'e,
Euen of Religion, to be euer one,
One soule, one flesh, one loue, one heart, one All?

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Haue done vnhappy youth, for thou art lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Shall then, (for that I am her brother borne)
My ioyes be euer banisht from her bed?
No Father; in your eyes I see the change.
Of pitty and compassion: from your age
As from a sacred Oracle. distills
The life of Counsell: tell mee holy man,
What Cure shall giue me ease in these extreames.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Repentance (sonne) and sorrow for this sinne:
For thou hast mou'd a Maiesty aboue
With thy vn-rannged (almost) Blasphemy.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: O doe not speake of that (deare Confessor)

SP.SPEAKER: Fry,
SP.L: Art thou (my sonne) that miracle of Wit,
Who once within these three Moneth's wert esteem'd
A wonder of thine age, throughout Bononia?
How did the Vniuersity applaud
Thy Gouerment, Behauiour, Learning, Speech,
Sweetnesse, and all that could make vp a man?
I was proud of my Tutellage, and chose
Rather to leaue my Bookes, then part with thee,
I did so: but the fruites of all my hopes
Are lost in thee, as thou art in thy selfe.
O Giouanni: hast thou left the Schooles
Of Knowledge, to conuerse with Lust and Death?
(For Death waites on thy Lust) looke through the World,
And thou shalt see a thousand faces shine
More glorious, then this Idoll thou ador'st:
Leaue her, and take thy choyce, 'tis much lesse sinne,
Though in such gamos as those, they lose that winne.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: It were more ease to stop the Ocean
From floates and ebbs, then to disswade my vower.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Then I haue done, and in thy wilfull flame:
Already see thy ruine; Heauen is iust,
Yet heare my counsell.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: As a voyce of life.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Hye to thy Fathers house, there locke thee fast
Alone within thy Chamber, then fall downe
On both thy knees, and grouell on the ground:
Cry to thy heart, wash euery word thou vtter'st
In teares, (and if't bee possible) of blood:
Begge Heauen to cleanse the leprosie of Lust
That rots thy Soule, acknowledge what thou art,
A wretch, a worme, a nothing: weepe, sigh, pray
Three times a day, and three times euery night:
For seuen dayes space doe this, then if thou find'st
No change in thy desires, returne to me:
I'le thinke on remedy, pray for thy selfe
At home, whil'st I pray for thee here—away,
My blessing with thee, wee haue neede to pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: All this I'le doe, to free mee from the rod
Of vengeance, else I'le sweare, my Fate's my God,

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Grimaldi and Vasques ready to fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: Come sir, stand to your tackling, if you proue Crauen,
I'le make you run quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: Thou art no equall match for mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: Indeed I neuer went to the warres to bring home newes, nor cannot play the Mountibanke for a meales meate, and sweare I got my wounds in the field: see you these gray haires, they'le not flinch for a bloody nose, wilt thou to this geere?

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.P:
Why slaue, think'st thou I'le ballance my reputation
With a Cast-suite; Call thy Maister, he shall know that I dare—

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: Scold like a Cot-queane (that's your Profession) thou poore shaddow of a Souldier, I will make thee know, my Maister keepes Seruants, thy betters in quality and performance: Com'st thou to fight or prate?

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: Neither with thee,
I am a Romane. and a Gentleman, one that haue got
Mine honour with expence of blood,

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: You are a lying Coward, and a foole, fight, or by these Hilts
I'le kill thee—braue my Lord,—you'le fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: Prouoake me not, for if thou dost—

DIV2.STAGE: They fight, Gri∣mal. hath the worst

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: Haue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: What meaned these sudden broyles so neare my dores?
Haue you not other places, but my house
To vent the spleene os your disordered bloods?
Must I be haunted still with such vnrest,
As not to eate, or sleepe in peace at home?
Is this your loue Grimaldi? Fie, t'is naught.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: And Vasques. I may tell thee 'tis not well
To broach these quarrels, you are euer forward
In seconding contentions.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: What's the ground?

SP.SPEAKER: Sor.
SP.L: That with your patience Signiore, I'le resolue
This Gentleman, whom same reports a souldier,
(For else I know not) riuals mee in loue
To Signior Florio's Daughter; to whose eares
He still preferrs his suite to my disgrace,
Thinking the way to recommend himselfe,
Is to disparage me in his report:
But know Grimaldi, though (may be) thou art
My equall in thy blood, yet this bewrayes
A lownesse in thy minde; which wer't thou Noble
Thou would it as much disdaine, as I doe thee
For this vnworthinesse; and on this ground
I will'd my Seruant to dorrest this tongne,
Holding a man, so base, no match for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: And had your sudda ne comming prevented vs, I had let my Gentleman blood vnder the gilles; I should haue worm'd you Sir, for running madde.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: Ile be reueng'd Soranzo.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas
SP.P: On a dish of warme-broth to stay your stomack, doe honest Innocence, doe; spone-meat is a wholesomer dyet then a spannish blade.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: remember this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sor.
SP.L: I feare thee not Grimaldi.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: My Lord Soranzo, this is strange to me,
Why you should storme, hauing my word engag'd:
Owing her heart, what ne you doubt her are?
Loosers may talke by law of any game.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: Yet the villaine of words, signior Florio may be such,
As would make any vnspleen'd Doue, Chollerick,
Blame not my Lord in this.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Be you more silent,
I would not for my wealth, my daughters loue
Should cause the spilling of one drop of blood.
Vasques put vp, let's end this fray in wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Putana
SP.P: How like you this child? here's threatning challeng∣ing, quarrelling, and fighting, on euery side, and all is for your sake; you had neede looke to your selfe (Chardge) you'le be stolne away sleeping else shortly.

SP.SPEAKER: Annabella:
SP.L: But (Tutresse) such a life, giues no content
To me, my thoughts are fixt on other ends;
Would you would leaue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.L: Leaue you? no maruaile else; leaue me, no leauing (Chardge)
This is loue outright, Indeede I blame you not, you haue
Choyce fit for the best Lady in Italy.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Pray doe not talke so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.P:
Take the worst with the best, there's Grimaldi the souldier a very well-timbred fellow: they say he is a Roman, Nephew to the Duke Mount Ferratto, they say he did good ser∣vice in the warrs against the Millanoys, but faith (Chardge) I doe not like him, and be for nothing, but for being a souldier; one a∣mongst
twenty of your skirmishing Captaines, but haue some pryuie may me or other, that marres their standing vpright, I like him the worse, hee crinckles so much in the hams; though hee might serue, if their were no more men, yet hee's not the man I would choose.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Fye how thou prat'st.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.P: As I am a very woman, I like Signiour Soranzo, well; hee is wise, and what is more, rich; and what is more then that, kind, and what is more then all this, a Noble-man; such a one were I the faire Annabella, my selfe, I would wish and pray for: then hee is bountifull; beside hee is handsome, and, by my troth, I thinke wholsome: (and that's newes in a gallant of three and twenty.) liberall that I know: louing, that you know; and a man sure, else hee could neuer ha' purchast such a good name, with Hippolita the lustie Widdow in her husbands life time: And t'were but for that report (sweet heart) would'a were thine: Commend a man for his qualities, but take a husband as he is a plaine-sufficient, naked man: such a one is for your bed, and such a one is Signior Soranzo my life for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Sure the woman tooke her mornings Draught to soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.L: But looke (sweet heart,) looke what thinge comes now:
Here's another of your cyphers to fill vp the number:
Oh braue old Ape in a silken Coate, obserue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Did'st thou thinke Poggi, that I would spoyle my
New cloathes, and leaue my dinner to fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: No Sir, I did not take you for so arrant a babie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: I am wyser then so: for I hope Poggio. thou
Neuer heard'st of an elder brother, that was a Coxcomb,
Did'st Poggio?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Neuer indeede Sir, as long as they had either land or mony left them to inhe rit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P:
Is it possible Poggio? oh monstruous! why Ile vnder∣take, with a handfull of siluer, to buy a headfull of wit at any tyme, but sirrah, I haue another purchase in hand, I shall haue the wench myne vnckle sayes, I will but wash my face, and shift socks, and then haue at her yfaith—
Marke my pace Poggio.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Sir I haue seene an. Asse, and a Mule trot the Spannish auin with a better grace, I know not how often.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: This Ideot haunts me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.P: I, I, he needes no discription, the rich Magnifico, that is below with your Father (Chardge) Signior Donado his Vnckle; for that he meanes to make this his Cozen a golden calfe, thinkes that you wil be a right Isralite, and fall downe to him presently: but I hope I haue tuterd you better: they say a fooles bable is a Ladies play fellow: yet you hauing wealth enough, you neede not cast vpon the dearth of flesh at any rate: hang him Innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: But see Putana, see: what blessed shape
Of some caelestiall Creature now appeares?
What man is hee, that with such sad aspect
Walkes carelests os him selfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.L: Where

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Looke below.

SP.SPEAKER: Put,
SP.L: Oh, 'tis your brother sweet—

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.L: 'Tis your brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna,
SP.L: Sure 'tis not hee, this is some woefull thinge
Wrapt vp in griefe, some shaddow of a man.
Alas hee beats his brest, and wipes his eyes
Drown'd all in teares: me thinkes I heare him sigh.
Lets downe Putana? and pertake the cause,
I know my Brother in the Loue he beares me,
Will not denye me partage in his sadnesse,
My soule is full of heauinesse and feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Lost, I am lost: my fates haue doom'd my death:
The more I striue, I loue, the more I loue,
The lesse I hope: I see my ruine, certaine.
What Iudgement, or endeuors could apply
To my incurable and restlesse wounds,
I throughly haue examin'd, but in vaine:
O that it were not in Religion sinne,
To make our loue a God, and worship it.
I haue euen wearied heauen with prayers, dryed vp
The spring of my continuall teares, euen steru'd
My veines with dayly fasts: what wit or Art
Could Counsaile, I haue practiz'd; but alas
I find all these but dreames, and old mens tales
To ight vnsteedy youth; I'me still the same,
Or I must speake, or burst; tis not I know,
My lust; but tis my fare that leads me on.
Keepe feare and low faint hearted shame with slaues,
Ile tell her, that I loue her, though my heart
Were rated at the price of that attempt.
Oh me! she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: If such a thing
As Courage dwell in men, (yee heauenly powers)
Now double all that vertue in my tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Why Brother, will you not speake to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Yes; how d'ee Sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Howsoeuer I am, me thinks you are not well.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.L: Blesse vs why are you so sad Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Let me intreat you leaue vs a while, Putana,
Sister, I would be pryuate with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: With-drawe Putana.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.P: I will, If this were any other Company for her, I should thinke my ab∣sence an office of some credit; but I will leaue them together.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Come Sister lend your hand, let's walke together.
I hope you neede not blush to walke with mee,
Here's none but you and I.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Faith I meane no harme.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Harme?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: No good faith; how ist with'ee?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: I trust hee be not franticke
I am very well brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Trust me but I am sicke, I feare so sick,
'Twill cost my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Mercy forbid it: 'tis not so I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: I thinke you loue me Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Yes you know, I doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: I know't indeed—y'are very faire.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Nay then I see you haue a merry sicknesse,

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: That's as it proues: they Poets faigne (I read)
That Iuno for her forehead did exceede
All other goddesses: but I durst sweare,
Your forehead exceeds hers, as hers did theirs.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Troth this is pretty.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Such a paire of starres.
As are thine eyes, would (like Promethean fire.)
(If gently glaun'st) giue life to senselesse stones.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Fie vpon'ee,

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: The Lilly and the Rose most sweetly strainge
Vpon your dimpled Cheekes doe striue for change.
Such lippes would tempt a Saint; such hands as those
Would make an Anchoret Lasciuious.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: D'ee mock mee', or flatter mee,

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: If you would see a beauty more exact
Then Art can counter fit, or nature frame,
Looke in your glasse, and there behold yourowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: O you are a trime youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Here.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: What to doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: And here's my breast, strick home.
Rip vp my bosome, there thou shalt behold
A heart, in which is writ the truth I speake.
Why stand'ee?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Are you earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Yes most earnest.
You cannot loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Whom.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Me, my tortur'd soule
Hath felt affliction in the heate of Death.
O Annabella I am quite vndone,
The loue of thee (my sister) and the view
Of thy immortall beauty hath vntun'd
All harmony both of my rest and life,
Why d'ee not strike?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Forbid it my iust feares,
If this be true, 'twere fitter I were dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: True Annabella; 'tis no time to iest,
I haue too long supprest the hidden flames
That almost haue consum'd me; I haue spent
Many a silent night in sighes and groanes,
Ran ouer all my thoughts, despis'd my Fate,
Reason'd against the reasons of my loue,
Done all that smooth'd-cheeke Vertue could aduise,
But found all bootelesse; 'tis my destiny,
That you must eyther loue, or I must dye.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Comes this in sadnesse from you?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio,
SP.L: Let some mischiefe
Befall me soone, if I dissemble ought.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: You are my brother Giouanni.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: You,
My Sister Annabella; I know this:
And could afford you instance why to loue
So much the more for this; to which intent
Wise Nature first in your Creation ment
To make you mine: else't had beene sinne and foule,
To share one beauty to a double soule.
Neerenesse in birth or blood, doth but perswade
A neerer neerenesse in affection.
I haue askt Counsell of the holy Church,
Who tells mee I may loue you, and 'tis iust,
That since I may, I should; and will, yes will:
Must I now liue, or dye?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Liue, thou hast wonne
The field, and neuer fought; what thou hast vrg'd,
My captiue heart had long agoe resolu'd.
I blush to tell thee, (but I'le tell thee now)
For euery sigh that thou hast spent for me,
I haue sigh'd ten; for euery teare shed twenty:
And not so much for that I lou'd, as that
I durst not say I lou'd; uor scarcely thinke it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Let not this Musicke be a dreame (yee gods)
For pittie's-sake I begge'ee.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: On my knees,
Brother, euen by our Mothers dust, I charge you,
Doe not betray mee to your mirth or hate,
Loue mee, or kill me Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: On my knees,
Sister, euen by my Mothers dust I charge you,
Doe not betray mee to your mirth or hate,
Loue mee, or kill mee Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: You meane good sooth then?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: In good troth I doe,
And so doe you I hope: say, I'm in earnest:

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: I'le swear't and I.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: And I, and by this kisse,
(Once more, yet once more, now let's rise, by this)
I would not change this minute for Elyzium,
What must we now doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: What you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Come then,
After so many teares as wee haue wept,
Let's learne to court in smiles, to kisse and sleepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Elo.
SP.L: Signior Donado, you haue sayd enough,
I vnderstand you, but would haue you know,
I will not force my Daughter 'gainst her will.
You see I haue but two, a Sonne and Her;
And hee is so deuoted to his Booke,
As I must tell you true, I doubt his health:
Should he miscarry, all my hopes rely
Vpon my Girle; as for worldly Fortune,
I am I thanke my Starres, blest with enough:
My Care is how to match her to her liking,
I would not haue her marry Wealth, but Loue,
And if she like your Nephew, let him haue her,
Here's all that I can say.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Sir you say well,
Like a true father, and for my part, I
If the young folkes can like, (twixt you and me')
Will promise to assure my Nephew presently,
Three thousand Florrens yeerely during life,
And after I am dead, my whole estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: 'Tis a faire proffer si, meane time your Nephew
Shall haue free passage to commence his suite;
If hee can thriue, hee shall haue my consent,
So for this time I'le leaue you Signior.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Well,
Here's hope yet, if my Nephew would haue wit,
But hee is such another Dunce, I feare
Hee'le neuer winne the Wench; when I was young
I could haue done't y faith, and so shall hee
If hee will learne of mee; and in good time
Hee comes himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: How now Bergetto, whether away so fast?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Oh Vnkle, I haue heard the strangest newes that euer came out of the Mynr, haue I not Poggio.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Yes indeede Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: What newes Bergetto?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Why looke yee Vnkle? my Barber told me iust now that there is a fellow come to Towne, who vndertakes to make a Mill goe without the mortall helpe of any water or winde, onely with Sand-bags: and this fellow hath a strange Horse, a most excellent beast, I'le assure you Vnkle, (my Barber sayes) whose head to the wonder of all Christian people, stands iust be∣hind where his tayle is, is't nor true Poggio?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: So the Barber swore for sooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: And you are running hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: I forsooth Vakle.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Wilt thou be a Foole stil? come sir, you shall not goe, you haue more mind of a Puppet-play, then on the businesse I told y'ee: why thou great Baby, wu't neuer haue wit, wu't make thy selfe a May-game to all the world?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Answere for your selfe Maister.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Why Vnkle, shu'd I sit at home still, and not goe abroad to see fashions like other gallants?

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: To see hobby-horses: what wise talke I pray had you with Annabella, when you were at Signior Florio's house?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Oh the wench: vds sa'me, Vnkle; I tickled her with a rare speech, that I made her almost burst her belly with laugh∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Nay I thinke so, and what speech was't?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: What did I say Poggio?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Fot sooth my Maister said, that hee loued her almost a∣well as hee loued Parmasent, and swore (I'le be sworne for him). that shee wanted but such a Nose as his was, to be as pretty a young woeman, as any was in Parma.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Oh grose!

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Nay Vnkle, then she ask't mee, whether my Father had any more children then my selfe: and I sayd no, 'twere better hee should haue had his braynes knockt out first.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: This is intolerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Then sayd shee, will Signior Donado your Vnkle leaue you all his wealth?

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Ha! that was good, did she harpe vpon that string?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Did she harpe vpon that string, I that she did: I answe∣red, leaue me all his wealth? why woeman, hee hath no other wit, if hee had, he should heare on't to his euer lasting glory and confusion: I know (quoth I) I am his white boy, and will not be guld: and with that she fell into a great smile, and went away. Nay I did fit her.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Ah sitrah, then I see there is no changing of nature,
Well Brgetto, I feare thou wilt be a very Asse still.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: I should be sorry for that Vnkle.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Come, come you home with me, since you are no better a speaker, I'le haue you wrte to her after some courtly manner, and close some rich I ewell in the Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: I marry, that will be excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Peace nnocent,
Once in my time I'le set my wits to schoole,
If all faile, 'tis but the fortune of a foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.L: Poggio, 'twill doe Poggio.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Secundus.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Giouanni and Annabella, as from their Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Come Annabella, no more Sister now,
But Loue; a name more Gracious, doe not blush,
(Beauties sweete wonder) but be proud, to know
That yeelding thou hast conquer'd, and inflam'd
A heart whose tribute is thy brothers life.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: And mine is his, oh how these stolne contents
Would print a modest Crymson on my cheekes,
Had any but my hearts delight preuail'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: I maruaile why the chaster of your sex
Should thinke this pretty toye call'd Maiden-head,
So strange a losse, when being lost, 'tis nothing,
And you are still the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: 'Tis well for you,
Now you can talke.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Musicke aswell consists
In th'eare, as in the playing.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Oh y'are wanton,
Tell on't, y'are best, doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Thou wilt chide me then,
Kisse me, so; thus hung Ioue on Laeda's necke,
And suck't diuine Ambrosia from her lips:
I enuy not the mightiest man aliue,
But hold my selfe in being King of thee,
More great, then were I King of all the world:
But I shall lose you Sweet-heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: But you shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: You must be married Mistres.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Yes, to whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Some one must haue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: You must.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Nay some other.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Now prithee do not speake so, without iesting
You'le make me weepe in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: What you will not.
But tell me sweete, can'st thou be dar'd to sweare
That thou wilt liue to mee, and to no other?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: By both our loues I dare, for didst thou know
My Gionanni, how all suiters seeme
To my eyes hatefull, thou wouldst trust mee then.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Enough, I take thy word; Sweet we must part,
Remember what thou vow'st, keepe well my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Will you begon?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: I must.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: When to returne?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Looke you doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Goe where thou wilt, in mind I'le keepe thee here,
And where thou art, I know I shall be there
Guardian.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.L: Child, how is't child? well, thanke Heauen, hal

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: O Guardian, what a Paradise of joy
Haue I past ouer!

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.P: Nay what a Paradise of ioy haue you past vnder? why now I commend thee (Chardge) feare nothing, (sweete∣heart) what though hee be your Brother; your Brother's a man I hope, and I say still, if a young Wench feele the fitt vpon her, let her take any body, Father or Brother, all is one.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: I would not haue it knowne for all the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.P: Nor I indeed, for the speech of the people; else 'twere nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Florio within—
SP.P: Daughter Annabella.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: O mee! my Father,—here Sir,—reach my worke.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo. within.
SP.P: What are you doeing?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: So, let him come now,

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Florio, Richardetto, like a Doctor of Phisicke, and Philotis with a Lute in her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: So hard at worke, that's well; you lose no time, looke, I haue brought you company, here's one, a learned Doctor, late∣ly come from Padua, much skild in Physicke, and for that I see you haue of late beene sickly, I entreated this reuerent man to visit you some time.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Y'are very welcome Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: I thanke you Mistresse,
Loud Fame in large report hath spoke your praise,
Aswell for Vertue as perfection:
For which I haue beene bold to bring with mee
A Kins-woeman of mine, a maide, for song,
And musicke, one perhaps will giue content,
Please you to know her.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: They are parts I loue,
And shee for them most welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Thanke you Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Sirnow you know my house, pray make not strange,
And if you finde my Daughter neede your Art,
I'le be your pay-master.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Sir, what I am shee shall command

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: You shall bind me to you,
Daughter, I must haue conference with you,
Aboutsome matters that concernes vs both.
Good Maister Doctor, please you but walke in,
Wee'le craue a little of your Cozens cunning:
I thinke my Girle hath not quite forgot
To touch an Instrument, she could haue don't,
Wee'le heare them both.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: I'le waite vpon you sir.
SP.STAGE: Enter Soranzo in his study reading a Booke.
SP.L: Loues measure is extreame, the comfort, paine:
The life vnrest, and the reward disdaine
What's here? looke o're againe, 'tis so, so writes
This smooth licentious Poet in his rymes.
But Sanazar thou lyest, for had thy bosome
Felt such oppression as is laid on mine,
Thou wouldst haue kist the rod that made the smart.
To worke then happy Muse, and contradict
What Sanazer hath in his enuy writ.
Loues measure is the meane, sweet his annoyes,
His pleasures life, and his reward all ioyes.
Had Annabella liu'd when Sanazar
Did in his briefe Euconium celebrate
Venice that Queene of Citties, he had left
That Verse which gaind him such a sume of Gold,
And for one onely looke from Annabell
Had writ of her, and her diuiner cheekes,
O how my thoughts are—

SP.SPEAKER: Vasques within—
SP.P: Pray forbeare, in rules of Ciuility, lot me giue notice on't: I shall be tax't of my neglect of duty and seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: What rude intrusion interrupts my peace,
Can I be no where priuate?

SP.SPEAKER: Vas. within.
SP.L: Troth you wrong your modesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: What's the matter Vasques, who is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: 'Tis I:
Doe you know mee now? looke periurd man on her
Whom thou and thy distracted lust haue wrong'd,
Thy sensuall rage of blood hath made my youth
Ascorne to men and Angels, and shall I
Be now a foyle to thy vnsated change?
Thou knowst (false wanton) when my modest fame
Stood free from staine, or scandall, all the charmes
Of Hell or sorcery could not preuaile
Against the honour of my chaster bosome:
Thyne eyes did pleade in teares, thy tongue in oathes
Such and so many, that a heart of steele
Would haue beene wrought to pity, as was mine:
And shall the Conquest of my lawfull bed,
My husbands death vrg'd on by his disgrace,
My losse of woeman-hood be ill rewarded
With hatred and contempt? No, know Soranzo,
I haue a spirit doth as much distast
The slauery of fearing thee, as thou
Dost loath the memory of what hath past.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Nay deare Hippolita.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Call me not deare,
Nor thinke with supple words to smooth the grosenesse
Of my abuses; 'tis not your new Mistresse,
Your goodly Madam Merchant shall triumph
On my deiection; tell her thus from mee,
My byrth was Nobler, and by much more Free.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: You are too violent.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: You are too double
In your dissimulation, see'st thou this,
This habit, these blacke mourning weedes of Care,
'Tis thou art cause of this, and hast diuore't
My husband from his life and me from him,
And made me Widdow in my widdow-hood.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Will you yet heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: More of the periuries?
Thy soule is drown'd too deepely in those sinnes,
Thou need'st not add to th number.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Then I'le leaue you,
You are past all rules of sence.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: And thou of grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: Fy Mistresse, you, are not neere the limits of reason, if my Lord had a resolution as noble as Vertue it selfe, you take the course to vnedge it all. Sir I beseech you doe not perplexe her, griefes (alas) will haue a vent, I dare vndertake Madam Hippo∣lita will now freely heare you.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Talke to a woman frantick, are these the fruits of your loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: They are the fruites of thy vntruth, false man,
Didst thou not sweare, whil'st no happinese on earth
More then to call me wife? didst thou not vow
When hee should dye to marry mee? for which
The Deuill in my blood, and thy protests
Caus'd mee to Counsaile him to vndertake
A voyage to Ligorne, for that we heard,
His Brother there was dead, and left a Daughter
Young and vnfriended, who with much adoe
I wish't him to bring hiher; hee did so,
And went; and as thou know'st dyed on the way.
Vnhappy man to buy his death so deare
With my aduice; yet thou for whom I did it,
Forget'st thy vowes, and leau'st me to my shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Who could helpe this?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Who? periur'd man thou couldst,
If thou hadst faith or loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: You are deceiu'd,
The vowes I made, (if you remember well)
Were wicked and vnlawfull,'twere more sinne
To keepe them, then to breake them; as for mee
I cannot maske my penitence, thinke thou
How much thou hast digrest from honest shame,
In bringing of a gentleman to death
Who was thy husband, such a one as hee,
So noble in his quality, condition,
Learning, behauiour, entertainment, loue,
As Parma could not shew a brauer man.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas,
SP.L: You doe not well, this was not your promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: I care not, let her know her monstrous life,
Ere I'le be seruile to so blacke a sinne,
I'le be a Curse; woeman, come here no more,
Leare to repent and dye; for by my honour
I hate thee and thy lust; you haue beene too foule.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: This part has beene scuruily playd.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: How foolishly this beast contemnes his Fate,
And shuns the vse of that, which I more scorne
Then I once lou'd his loue; but let him goe,
My vengeance shall giue comfort to his woe.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: Mistresse, Mistresse Madam Hippolita,
Pray a word or two.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: With mee Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: With you if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: What is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: I know you are infinitely mou'd now, and you thinke you haue cause, some I confesse you haue, but sure not so much as you imagine.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: O yo were miserably bitter, which you followed euen to the last llable: Faith you were somewhat too shrewd, by my life you could not haue tooke my Lord in a worse time, since I first knew him: tomorrow you shall finde him a new man.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Well, I shall waite his leasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: Fie, this is not a hearty patience, it comes sowerly from you, troth let me perswade you for once.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I haue it ad it shall be so; thanks opportunity
—perswade me to what—

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: Visitt him in some milder temper, O if you could but master a little your femall spleen, how might you winne him!

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P:
Hee wil neuer loue me: Vasques, thou hast bin a too trusty seruant to such a master, & I beleeue thy reward in the end wil fal
out like mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: So perhaps too.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Resolue thy selfe it will; had I one so true, so truely ho∣nest, so secret to my Counsels, as thou hast beene to him and his, I should thinke it a flight acquittance, not onely to make him Maister of all I haue, but euen of my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: O you are a noble Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Wu't thou feede alwayes vpon hopes? well, I know thou art wise, and see'st the reward of an old seruant dally what it is

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: Beggery and neglect.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: True, but Vasques, wer't thou mine, and wouldst bee priuate to me and my designes; I here protest my selfe, and all what I can else call myne, should be at thy dispose.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: Worke you that way old moule? then I haue the wind of you—I were not worthy of it, by any desert that could lye—within my compasse; if I could—

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: I should then hope to liue in these my old yeares with rest and security.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Giue me thy hand, now promise but thy silence,
And helpe to bring to passe a plot I haue;
And here in sight of Heauen, (that being done)
I make thee Lord of mee and mine estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: Come you are merry,
This is such a happinesse that I can
Neither thinke or beleeue.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Promise thy secresie, and 'tis confirm'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: Then here I call our good Genij foe-witnesses, whatso∣euer your designes are, or against whomsoeuer, I will not one∣ly be a speciall actor therein, but neuer disclose it till it be effected.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I take thy word, and with that, thee for mine:
Come then, let's more conferre of this anon.
On this delicious bane my thoughts shall banquet,
Reuenge shall sweeten what my griefes haue tasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Richar.
SP.L: Thou see'st (my louely Necce) these strange mishaps,
How all my fortunes turne to my disgrace,
Wherein I am but as a looker on,
Whiles others act my shame, and I am silent.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: But Vnkle, wherein can this borrowed shape
Giue you content?

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: I'le tell thee gentle Neece,
Thy wanton Aunt in her lascious riotts
Liues now secure, thinkes I am surely dead
In my late Iourney to Ligorne for you;
(As I haue caus'd it to be rumord out)
Now would I see with what an impudence
Shee giues scope to her loose adultery,
And how the Common voyce allowes hereof:
Thus farre I haue preuail'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Alas, I feare
You meane some strange reuenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: O be not troubled,
Your ignorance shall pleade for you in all,
But to our businesse, what, you learnt for certaine
How Signior Florio meanes to giue his Daughter
In marriage to Soranzo?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Yes for certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: But how finde you young Annabella's loue,
Inclind to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: For ought I could perceine,
Shee neyther fancies him or any else.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: There's Mystery in that which time must shew,
Shee vs'd you kindly.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: And crau'd your company?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Often.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: 'Tis well, it goes as I could wish,
I am the Doctor now, and as for you,
None knowes you; if all faile not we shall thrine.
But who comes here?
I know him, 'tis Grimaldi,
A Roman and a souldier, neere allyed
Vnto the Duke of Montferrato, one
Attending on the Nuntio of the Pope
That now resides in Parma, by which meanes
He hopes to get the loue of Annabella,

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: Saue you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: And you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: I haue heard
Of your approu'd skill, which through the City
Is freely talkt of, and would craue your ayd.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: For what Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: Marry sir for this—
But I would speake in Priuate.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Leaue vs Cozen.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: I loue faire Annabella, and would know
Whether in Arts there may not be receipts
To moue affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Sir perhaps there may,
But these will nothing profit you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: Not mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Vnlesse I be mistooke, you are a man
Greatly in fauour with the Cardinall.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: What of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: In duty to his Grace,
I will be bold to tell you, if you seeke
To marry Florio's daughter, you must first
Remoue a barre twixt you and her.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: Whose that?

SP.SPEAKER: Richard:
SP.L: Soranzo is the man that hath her heart,
And while hee liues, be sure you cannot speed.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: Soranzo, what mine Enemy, is't hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Is hee your Enemy?

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: The man I hate,
Worse then Confusion:
I'le tell him streight.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Nay, then take mine aduice,
(Euen for his Graces sake the Cardinall)
I'le finde a time when hee and shee doe meete,
Of which I'le giue you notice, and to be sure
Hee shall not scape you, I'le prouide a poyson
To dip your Rapiers poynt in, if hee had
As many heads as (Hidra had, he dyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: But shall I trust thee Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: As your selfe,
Doubt not in ought; thus shall the Fates derce,
By me Soranzo falls, that min'd mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Well Sir, I must bee content to be both your Secretary and your Messenger my selfe; I cannot tell what this Letter may worke, but as sure as I am aliue, if thou come ore to talke with her, I feare thou wu't marre whatsoeuer I make.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: You make Vnkle? why am not I bigge enough to car∣ry mine owne Letter I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: I, I carry a fooles head o'thy owne; why thou Dunce, wouldst thou write a letter, and carry it thy selfe

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Yes that I wudd, and reade it to her with my owne mouth, for you must thinke, if shee will not belecue me my selfe when she heares me speake; she will not beleeue anothers hand∣writing. O you thinke I am ablocke-head Vnkle, no sir, Pog∣gio knowes I haue indited a letter my selfe, so I haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Yes truely sir, I haue it in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: A sweate one no doubt, pray let's see't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: I cannot reade my owne hand very well Poggio, Reade it Poggio.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Begin.

LETTER.P: I could call you faire, lie as fast as any that loues you, but my Vnkle being the older man, I leaue it to him, as more fit for his age, and the colour of his beard: I am wise enough to tell you board where I see occasian, or if you like my Vnkles wit bet∣ter then mine, you shall marry mee; if you like mine better then his I will marry you in spight of your teeth; So commonding my best parts to you, I rest.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Yours vpwards and downewards, or you may chose, Bergetto.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Ah ha, here's stuffe Vnkle.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Here's stuffe indeed to shame vs all,
Pray whose aduice did you take in this learned Letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: None vpon my word, but mine owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: And mine Vnkle, beleeue it, no bodies else; 'twas mine owne brayne, I thanke a good wit for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Get you home sir, and looke yon keepe within doores till I returne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: How? that were a iest indeede; I scorne it yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: What you doe not?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Iudge me, but I doe now.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Indeede sir 'tis very vnhealthy.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Well sir, if I heare any of your apish running to motions, and fopperies till I come backe, you were as good no; looke too't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Poggio, shall's steale to see this Horse with the head in's tayle?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: I but you must take heeds of whipping.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Dost take me for a Child Poggio,
Come honest Poggio,

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Peace, thou hast told a tale, whose euery word
Threatens eternall flaughter to the soule:
I'me sorry I haue heard it; would mine eares
Had beene one minute deafe, before the houre
That thou cam'st to mee: o young man cast-away,
By the relligious number of mine order,
I day and might haue wak't my aged eyes,
Aboue thy strength, to weepe on thy behalfe:
But Heauen is angry, and be thou resolu'd,
Thou art a man remark't to tast a mischiefe,
Looke for't; though it come late, it will come sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Father, in this you are vncharitable;
What I haue done, I'le proue both fit and good.
It is a principall (which you haue taught
When I was yet your Scholler) that the Fame
And Composition of the Minde doth follow
The Frame and Composition of Body:
So where the Bodies furniture is Beauty,
The Mindes must needs be Vertue: which allowed.
Vertue it selfe is Reason but refin'd,
And Loue the Quintesence of that, this proues
My Sisters Beauty being rarely Faire,
Is rarely Vertuous; chiefely in her loue,
And chiefely in that Loue, her loue to me.
If hers to me, then so is mine to her;
Since in like Causes are effects alike.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: O ignorance in knowledge, long agoe,
How often haue I warn'd thee this before?
Indeede if we were sure there were no Deity,
Nor Heauen nor Hell, then to be lead alone,
By Natures light (as were Philosophers
Of elder times) might instance some defence.
But 'tis not so; then Madman, thou wilt finde,
That Nature is in Heauens positions blind.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Your age o're rules you, had you youth like mine,
You'd make her loue your heauen, and her diuine.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Nay then I see th'art too farre sold to hell,
It lies not in the Compasse of my prayers
To call thee backe; yet let me Counsell thee:
Perswade thy sister to some marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Marriage? why that's to dambe her; that's to prone
Her greedy of variety of lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: O fearefull! if thou wilt not, giue me leaue
To shriue her; lest shee should dye vn-absolu'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: At your best leasure Father, then shee'le tell you,
How dearely shee doth prize my Matchlesse loue,
Then you will know what pitty 'twere we two
Should haue beene sundred from each others armes.
View well her face, and in that little round,
You may obserue a world of variety;
For Colour, lips, for sweet perfumes, her breath;
For Iewels, eyes; for threds of purest gold,
Hayre; for delicious choyce of Flowers, cheekes;
Wonder in euery portion of that Throne:
Heare her but speake, and you will sweare the Sphaeres
Make Musicke to the Cittizens in Heauen:
But Father, what is else for pleasure fram'd,
Least I offend your eares shall goe vn-nam'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: The more I heare, I pitty thee the more,
That one so excellent should giue those parts:
All to a second Death; what I can doe
Is but to pray; and yet I could aduise thee,
Wouldst thou be rul'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: In what?

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Why leaue her yet,
The Throne of Mercy is aboue your trespasse,
Yet time is left you both—

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: To embrace each other,
Else let all time be strucke quite out of number;
Shee is like mee, and I like her resolu'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: No more, I'le visit her; this grieues me most,
Things being thus, a paire of soules are lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Where's Giouanni?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Newly walk't abroad,
And (as I heard him say) gon to the Fryar
His reuerent Tutor.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: That's a blessed man,
A man made vp of holinesse, I hope
Hee'le teach him how to gaine another world.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Faire Gentlewoman, here's a letter sent:
To you from my young Cozen, I dare sweare
He loues you in his soule, would you could heare
Sometimes, what I see dayly, sighes and teares,
As if his breast were prison to his heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Receiue it Annabella.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Alas good man.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: What's that she said?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.P: And please you sir, she sayd, alas good man, truely I doe Commend him to her euery night before her first sleepe, because I would haue her dreame of him, and shee harkens to that most relligiously.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P:
Say'st so, godamercy Putana there's something for thee, and prythee doe what thou canst on his behalfe; sha'not
be lost labour, take my word for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.P: Thanke you most heartily sir, now I haue a Feeling of your mind, let mee alone to worke.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Guardian!

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.P: Did you call?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Keepe this letter,

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Signior Florio, in any case bid her reade it instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Keepe it for what? pray reade it mee here right.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: I shall sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: How d'ee finde her inclin'd Signior

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Troth sir I know not how; not all so well
As I could wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Sir I am bound to rest your Cozens debter,
The Iewell I'le returne, for if he loue,
I'le count that loue a Iewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Marke you that?
Nay keepe them both sweete Maide.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: You must excuse mee,
Indeed I will not keepe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Where's the Ring,
That which your Mother in her will bequeath'd,
And charg'd you on her blessing not to giue't
To any but your Husband? send backe that.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: I haue it not,

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Ha I haue it not, where is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: My brother in the morning tooke it frō me,
Said he would weare't to Day.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Well, what doe you say
To young Bergetto's loue? are you content
To match with him? speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: There's the poynt indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: What shal I doe, I must say something now.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: What say, why d'ee not speake?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Sir with your leaue
Please you to giue me freedome.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Yes you haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Signior Donado, if your Nephew meane
To rayse his better Fortunes in his match,
The hope of mee will hinder such a hope;
Sir if you loue him, as I know you doe;
Find one more worthy of his choyce then mee,
In short, I'me sure, I sha'not be his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Why here's plaine dealing, I commend thee for't,
And all the worst I wish thee, is heauen blesse thee,
Your Father yet and I will still be friends,
Shall we not Signior Florio?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Yes, why not?
Looke here your Cozen comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Oh Coxcombe, what doth he make here?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Where's my Vnkle firs.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: What's the newes now?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Saue you Vnkle saue you, you must not thinke I come for nothing Maisters, and how and how is't? what you haue read my letter, ah, there I—tickled you yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: But 'twere better you had tickled her in another place.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Sirrah Sweet-heat, I'le tell thee a good jest, and riddle what 'tis.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: You say you'd tell mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: As I was walking iust now in the Streete, I mett a swaggering fellow would needs take the wall of me, and be∣cause hee did thrust me, I very valiantly cal'd him Rogue, hee hereupon bad me drawe, I told him I had more wit then so, but when hee saw that I would not, hee did so maule me with the hilts of his Rapier, that my head sung whil'st my feere caper'd in the kennell.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Was euer the like asse seene?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: And what did you all this while?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P:
Laugh at him for a gull, till I see the blood runne about mine eares, and then I could not choose but finde in my heart to cry; till a fellow with a broad beard; (they say hee is a new-come Doctor) cald mee into this house, and gaue me a playster, looke you here 'tis; and sir there was a young wench washt my face and hands most excellently, yfaith I shall loue
her as long as I liue for't, did she not Poggio?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Yes and kist him too.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Why la now, you thinke I tell a lye Vnkle I warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Would hee that beate thy blood out of thy head, had beaten some wit into it; For I feare thou neuer wilt haue any.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Oh Vnkle, but there was a wench, would haue done a mans heart good to haue lookt on her, by this light shee had a face mee-thinks worth twenty of you Mistresse Annabella.

SP.SPEAKER: Do,
SP.P: Was euer such a foole borne?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: I am glad shee lik't you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Are you so, by my troth I thanke you forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Sure 'twas the Doctors neece, that was last day with vs here:

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: 'Twas shee, 'twas shee.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: How doe you know that simplicity?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Why doe's not hee say so? if I should hau sayd no, I should hau giuen him the lye Vnkle, and so haue deseru'd a dry beating againe; I'le none of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: A very modest welbehau'd young Maide as I haue seene.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Is shee indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Indeed Shee is, if I haue any Iudgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Well sir, now you are free, you need not care for send∣ing letters, now you are dismist, your Mistresse here will none of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: No; why what care I for that, I can haue Wenches e∣nough in Parma for halfe a Crowne a peece, cannot I Poggio?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: I'le warrant you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Signior Florio, I thanke you for your free recourse you gaue for my admittance; and to you faire Maide that Iewell I will giue you 'gainst your marriage, come will you goe sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: I marry will I Mistres, farwell Mistres, I'le come a∣gaine to morrow—farwell Mistres.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Sonne, where haue you beene? what alone, alone, still, still? I would not haue it so, you must forsake this ouer book∣ish humour. Well, your Sister hath shooke the Foole off.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: 'Twas no match for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: 'Twas not indeed I ment it nothing lesse,
Soranzo is the man I onely like;
Looke on him Annabella, come, 'tis supper-time,
And it growes late.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Whose ewell's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Some Sweet-hearts.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: So I thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: A lusty youth, Signior Donado gaue it me
To weare against my Marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: But you shall not weare it, send it him backe againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: What, you are jealous?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: That you shall know anon, at better leasure:
Welcome sweete night, the Euening crownes the Day.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Tertius.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: DO'es my Vnkle thinke to make mee a Baby still? no,
Poggio, he shall know, I haue a skonce now.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: I let him not bobbe you off like an Ape with an apple.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Sfoot, I will haue the wench, if he were tenne Vnkles, in despight of his nose Poggio.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Hold him to the Grynd-stone, and giue not a jot of ground, Shee hath in a manner promised you already.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: True Poggio, and her Vnkle the Doctor
Swore I should marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: He swore I remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: And I will haue her that's more; did'st see the codpeice∣poynt she gaue me, and the box of Mermalade?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Very well, and kist you, that my chopps watred at the sight on't; there's no way but to clap vp a marriage in hugger mugger.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P:
I will do't for I tell thee Poggio, I begin to grow valiant
methinkes, and my courage begins to rise.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Should you be afraid of your Vnkle?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Hang him old doating Rascall, no, I say I will haue her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Lose no time then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: I will beget a race of Wise men and Constables, that shall cart whoores at their owne charges, and breake the Dukes peace ere I haue done my selfe.—come away.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Florio, Giouanni, Soranzo, Annabella, Putana and Vasques.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: My Lord Soranzo, though I must confesse,
The proffers that are made me, haue beene great
In marriage of my daughter; yet the hope
Of your still rising honours, haue preuaild
Aboue all other Ioynctures; here shee is,
She knowes my minde, speake for your selfe to her,
And heare you daughter, see you vse him nobly,
For any priuate speech, I'le giue you time:
Come sonne and you, the rest let them alone,
Agree as they may.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: I thanke you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Sister be not all woeman, thinke on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Vasques?

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Attend me without—

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Sir what's your will with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Doe you not know what I should tell you?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Yes, you'le say you loue mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: And I'le sweare it too; will you beleeue it?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: 'Tis not poynt of faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Haue you not will to loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Not you.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Whom then?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: That's as the Fates inferre.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Of those I'me regient now.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: What meane you sweete?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: To liue and dye a Maide.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Oh that's vnfit.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Here's one can say that's but a womans noate.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Did you but see my heart, then would you sweare—

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: That you were dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: That's true, or somewhat neere it.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: See you these true loues teares?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Now shee winkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: They plead to you for grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Yet nothing speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Oh grant my suite.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: What is't

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: To let mee liue.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Take it—.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Still yours.—

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: That is not mine to giue.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: One such another word would kil his hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.P: Mistres, to leaue those fruitlesse strifes of wit, I know I haue lou'd you long, and lou'd you truely; Not hope of what you haue, but what you are Haue drawne me on, then let mee not in vaine Still feele the rigour of your chast disdaine. I'me sicke, and sicke to th'heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Helpe, Aquavitae

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.P: What meane you?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Why I thought you had beene sicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.P: Doe you mocke my loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.P: There sir shee was too nimble.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.P: 'Tis plaine; shee laughes at me, these scornefull taunts neither become your modesty, or yeares.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: You are no looking-glasse, or if you were, I'de dresse my language by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.P: I'me confirm'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: To put you out of doubt, my Lord, mee-thinks your Common sence should make you vnderstand, that if I lou'd you, or desir'd your loue, some way I should haue giuen you better tast: but since you are a Noble man, and one I wouldnot wish should spend his youth in hopes, let mee aduise you here, to for∣beare your suite, and thinke I wish you well, I tell you this.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Is't you speake this?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Yes, I my selfe; yet know
Thus farre I giue you comfort, if mine eyes
Could haue pickt out a man (amongst all those
That sue'd to mee) to make a husband of,
You should haue beene that man; let this suffice,
Be noble in your secresie and wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Why now I see shee loues me.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: One word more:
As euer Vertue liu'd within your mind,
As euer noble courses were your guide.
As euer you would haue me know you lou'd me,
Let not my Father know hereof by you:
If I hereafter finde that I must marry,
It shall be you or none.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: I take that promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Oh, oh my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: What's the matter, not well?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Oh I begin to sicken.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Heauen forbid.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Helpe, helpe, within there ho.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Looke to your daughter Signior Florio.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Hold her vp, shee sounes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Sister how d'ee?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Sicke, brother, are you there?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Conuay her to her bed instantly, whil'st I send for a Phi∣sitian, quickly I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.L: Alas poore Child.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Oh Vasques, now I doubly am vndone.
Both in my present and my future hopes:
Shee plainely told me, that shee could not loue,
And thereupon soone sickned, and I feare
Her life's in danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: Byr lady Sir, and so is yours, if you knew all.—las sir, I am sorry for that, may bee 'tis but the Maides sicknesse, an o∣uer-fluxe of youth and then sir, there is no such presentremedy, as present Marriage. But hath shee giuen you an absolute deniall?

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: She hath, and she hath not; I'me full of griefe,
But what she sayd, 'le tell thee as we goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.L: Oh sir, wee are all vndone, quite vndone, vtterly vndone,
And sham'd foreuer; your sister, oh your sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: What of her? for Heauens sake speake, how do'es shee?

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.P: Oh that euer I was borne to see this day.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.P: She is not dead, ha, is shee?

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.L: Dead? no, shee is quicke, 'tis worse, she is with childe,
You know what you haue done; Heauen forgiue'ce,
'Tis too late to repent, now Heauen helpe vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: With child? how dost thou know't?

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.P: How doe I know't? am I at these yeeres ignorant, what the meaning's of Quames, and Waterpangs be? of changing of Colours, Quezinesse of stomacks, Pukings, and another thing that I could name; doe not (for her and your Credits sake) spend the time in asking how, and which way, 'tis so; shee is quick vpon my word, if you let a Phisitian see her water y'are vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: But in what case is shee?

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.P: Prettily amended, 'twas but a fit which I soone espi'd, and she must looke for often hence-forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Commend me to her, bid her take no care,
Let not the Doctor visit her I charge you,
Make some excuse, till I returne; oh mee,
I haue a world of businesse in my head,
Doe not discomfort her; how doe this newes perplex mee!
If my Father come to her, tell him shee's recouer'd well,
Say 'twas but some ill dyet; d'ee heare Woeman,
Looke you to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Put.
SP.L: I will sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: And how d'ee finde her sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Indifferent well,
I see no danger, scarse perceiue shee's sicke,
But that shee told mee, shee had lately eaten
Mellownes, and as shee thought, those disagreed
With her young stomacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Did you giue her ought?

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: An easie surfeit water, nothing else,
You neede not doubt her health; I rather thinke
Her sicknesse is a fulnesse of her blood,
You vnderstand mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: I doe; you counsell well,
And once within these few dayes, will so order't
She shall be married, ere shee know the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Yet let not hast (sir) make vnworthy choice,
That were dishonour.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Maister Doctor no,
I will not doe so neither, in plaine words
My Lord Soranzo is the man I meane.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: A noble and a vertuous Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: As any is in Parma; not farre hence,
Dwels Father Bonauenture, a graue Fryar,
Once Tutor to my Sonne; now at his Cell
I'le haue'em married.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: You haue plotted wisely.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: I'le send one straight
To speake with him to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Soranzo's wise, he will delay no time.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: It shall be so

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Good peace be here and loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Welcome relligious Fryar, you are one,
That still bring blessing to the place you come to.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Sir, with what speed I could, I did my best,
To draw this holy man from forth his Cell,
To visit my sicke sistr, that with words
Of ghostly comfort in this time of neede,
Hee might absolue her, whether she liue or dye.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: 'Twas well done Giouanni, thou herein
Hast shewed a Christians care, a Brothers loue
Come Father, I'le conduct you to her chamber,
And one thing would intreat you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Say on sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: I haue a Fathers deare impression,
And wish before I fall into my graue,
That I might see her married, as 'tis fit;
A word from you Graue man, will winne her more,
Then all our best perswasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Gentle Sir,
All this I'le say, that Heauen may prosper her.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: Now if the Doctor keepe his word, Soranzo,
Twenty to one you misse your Bride; I know
'Tis an vnnoble act, and not becomes
A Souldiers vallour; but in termes of loue,
Where Merite cannot sway, Policy must.
I am resolu'd, if this Phisitian
Play not on both hands, then Soranzo falls.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: You are come as I could wish, this very night So∣ranzo,
'tis ordain'd must bee affied to Annabella; and for ought
I know, married.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Yet your patience,
The place, 'tis Fryars Bonauentures Cell.
Now I would wish you to bestow this night,
In watching thereabouts, 'tis but a night,
If you misse now, to morrow I'le know all.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: Haue you the poyson?

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Here 'tis in this Box,
Doubt nothing, this will-doe't; in any case
As you respect your life, be quicke and sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: I'le speede him.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Doe; away, for 'tis not safe
You should be seene much here—euer my loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: And mine to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: So, if this itt, I'le laugh and hug reuenge;
And they that now dreame of a weddingfeast,
May chance to mourne the lusty Bridegromes ruine.
But to my other businesse; Neice Philotis.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Vnkle.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: My louely Neece, you haue bethought'ee.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Yes, and as you counsel'd,
Fashion'd my heart to loue him, but hee sweares
Hee will to night be married; for he feares
His Vnkle else, if hee should know the drift,
Wll hinder all, and call his Couze to shrift.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: To night? why best of all; but let mee see,
I—ha—yes,—so it shall be; in disguise
Wee'le earely to the Fryars, I haue thought on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Vnkle, hee comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Welcome my worthy Couze.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: I asse pretty Lasse, come busse Lassae, a ha Poggio.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: There's hope of this yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: You shall haue time enough, withdraw a little,
Wee must conferre at large.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Haue you notsweete-meates, or dainty deuices for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: You shall enough Sweet-heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Sweet-heart, marke that Poggio; by my troth I cannot choose but kisse thee once more for that word Sweet-heart; Pog∣gio, I haue a monstrous swelling about my stomacke, whatsoeuer the matter be.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: You shall haue Phisick for't sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Time runs apace.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Time's a blockhead.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Be rul'd, when wee haue done what's fitt to doe,
Then you may kisse your fill, and bed her too.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter the Fryar in his study, sitting in a chayre, Annabella knee∣ling and whispering to him, a Table before them and wax-lights, she weepes, and wrings her hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: I am glad to see this pennance; for beleeue me,
You haue vnript a soule, so foule and guilty.
As I must tell you true, I maruaile how
The earth hath borne you vp, but weepe, weepe on,
These teares may doe you good; weepe faster yet,
Whiles I doe reade a Lecture.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Wretched creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: I, you are wretched, miserably wretched.
Almost condemn'd aliue; there is a place
(List daughter) in a blacke and hollow Vault,
Where day is neuer seene; there shines no Sunne,
But flaming horrour of consuming Fires;
A lightlesse Suphure, choakt with smoaky foggs
Of an infected darknesse; in this place
Dwell many thousand, thousand sundry sorts
Of neuer dying deaths; there damned foules
Roare without pitty, there are Gluttons fedd
With Toades and Addars; there is burning Oyle
Powr'd downe the Drunkards throate, the Vsurer
Is for't to supp whole draughts of molten Gold;
There is the Murtherer for-euer stab'd,
Yet can he neuer dye; there lies the wanton
On Racks of burning steele, whiles in his soule
Hee feeles the torment of his raging lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Mercy, oh mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: There stands these wretched things.
Who haue dream't out whole yeeres in lawlesse sheets
And secret incests, cursing one another;
Then you will wish, each kisse your brother gaue,
Had beene a Daggers poynt; then you shall heare
How hee will cry, oh would my wicked sister
Had first beene damn'd, when shee did yeeld to lust.
But soft, methinkes I see repentance worke
New motions in your heart, say? how is't with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Is there no way left to redeeme my miseries?

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: There is, despaire not; Heauen is mercifull,
And offers grace euen now; 'tis thus agreed,
First, for your Honours safety that you marry
The Lord Soranzo, next, to saue your soule,
Leaue off this life, and henceforth liue to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Ay mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Sigh not, I know the baytes of sinne
Are hard to leaue, oh 'tis a death to doe't.
Remember what must come, are you content?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: I like it well, wee'le take the time,
Who's neere vs there?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Did you call Father?

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Is Lord Soranzo come?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Heestayes belowe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Haue you acquainted him at full?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: I haue and hee is ouer-ioy'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: And so are wee: bid him come neere.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: My Sister weeping, ha? I feare this Fryars falshood,
I will call him.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Daughter, are you resolu'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Father, I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: My Lord Soranzo, here
Giue mee your hand, for that I giue you this.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Lady, say you so too?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: I doe, and vow, to liue with you and yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Timely resolu'd:
My blessing rest on both, more to be done,
You may performe it on the Morning-sun.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Grimaldi with his Rapier drawne, and a Darke-lanthorne.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: 'Tis early night as yet, and yet too soone
To finish such a worke; here I will lye
To listen who comes next.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Bergetto and Philotis disguis'd, and after Richardetto and Poggio.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Wee are almost at the place, I hope Sweet-heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: I heare them neere, and heard one say Sweet-heart,
'Tis hee; now guide my hand some angry Iustice
Home to his bosome, now haue at you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Oh helpe, helpe, here's a stich fallen in my gutts,
Oh for a Flesh-taylor quickly—Poggio.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: What ayles my loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: I am sure I cannot pisse forward and backward and yet
I am wet before and behind, lights, lights, ho lights.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Alas, some Villaine here has slaine my loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Oh Heauen forbid it; raise vp the next neighbours
Instantly Poggio, and bring lights,
How is't Bergetto? slaine?
It cannot be; are you sure y'are hurt?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: O my belly seeths like a Porridge-pot, some cold water I shall boyle ouer else; my whole body is in a sweat, that you may wring my shirt; feele here—why Poggio.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Poggio with Officers, and lights and Halberts.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Here; alas, how doe you?

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Giue me a light, what's here? all blood! O sirs,
Signior Donado's Nephew now is slaine,
Follow the murtherer with all the haste
Vp to the Citty, hee cannot be farre hence,
Follow I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Officers.
SP.L: Follow, follow, follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Teare off thy linnen Couz, to stop his wounds,
Be of good comfort man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Is all this mine owne blood? ay then good-night with me, Poggio. commend me to my Vkle, dost heare? bid him for my sake make much of this wench, oh—I am going the wrong way sure, my bey akes so—oh farwell, Poggio—oh—oh—

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: O hee is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: How! dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: Hee's dead indeed,
'Tis now to late to weepe, let's haue him home,
And with what speed we may, finde out the Murtherer.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Oh my Maister, my Maister, my Maister.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Betroath'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: I saw it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: And when's the marriage-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: Some two dayes hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Two dayes? Why man I would but wish two houres
To send him to his last, and lasting sleepe.
And Vasques thou shalt see, I'le doe it brauely.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: I doe not doubt your wisedome, nor (I trust) you my secreie,
I am infinitely yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I wilbe thine inspight of my disgrace,
So soone? o wicked man, I durst be sworne,
Hee'd laugh to see mee weepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: And that's a Villanous fault in him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: No, let him laugh, I'me arm'd in my resolue
Be thou still true.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: I should get little by treachery against so hopefull a pre∣ferment,
as I am like to climbe to.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Euen to my bosome Vasques, let My youth
Reuell in these new pleasures, if wee thriue,
Hee now hath but a paire of dayes to liue.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Florio, Donado, Richardetto, Poggio and Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: 'Tis bootlesse now to shew your selfe a child
Signior Donado, what is done, is done;
Spend not the time in teares, but seeke for Iustice.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: I must confesse, somewhat I was in fault,
That had not first acquainted you what loue
Past twixt him and my Neece, but as I liue,
His Fortune grieues me as it were mine owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Ala poore Creature, he ment no man harme,
That I am sure of.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: I beleeue that too;
But stay my Maisters, are you sure you saw
The Murtherer passe here?

SP.SPEAKER: Offic.
SP.L: And it please you sir, wee are sure wee saw a Ruffian
with a naked weapon in his hand all bloody, get into my Lord
Cardinals Graces gate, that wee are sure of; but for feare of his
Grace (blesse vs) we durst goe no further.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Know you what manner of man hee was?

SP.SPEAKER: Offic.
SP.L: Yes sure I know the man, they say a is a souldier, hee
that lou'd your daughter Sir an't please y'ee, 'twas hee for cer∣taine.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Grimaldi on my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Offic.
SP.L: I, I, the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Richard.
SP.L: The Cardinall is Noble, he no doubt
Will giue true Iustice.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Knocke some one at the gate,

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: I'le knocke sir.
Seruant within. What would'ee?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Wee require speech with the Lord Cardinall
About some present businesse, pray informe
His Grace, that we are here.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Why how now friends? what sawcy mates are you
That know nor duty nor Ciuillity?
Are we a person fit to be your hoast?
Or is our house become your common Inne
To beate our dores at pleasure? what such haste
Is yours as that it cannot waite fit times?
Are you the Maisters of this Common-wealth
And know no more discretion? oh your newes
Is here before you, you haue lost a Nephew
Donado, last night by Grimaldi slaine:
Is that your businesse? well sir, we haue knowledge
Le that suffice.

SP.SPEAKER: Gri.
SP.L: In presence of your Grace,
In thought I neuer ment Bergetto harme,
But Florio you can tell, with how much scorne
Soranzo backt with his Confederates,
Hath often wrong'd mee; I to be reueng'd,
(For that I could not win him else to fight)
Had thought by way of Ambush to haue kild him,
But was vnluckely, therein mistooke;
Else hee had felt what late Bergetto did:
And though my fault to him were meerely chance,
Yet humbly I submit me to your Grace,
To doe with mee as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Rise vp Grimaldi,
You Cittizens of Parma, if you seeke
For Iustice; Know as Nuntio from the Pope,
For this offence I here receiue Grimaldi
Into his holinesse protection.
Hee is no Common man, but nobly borne;
Of Princes blood, though you Sir Florio,
Thought him to meane a husband for your daughter
If more you seeke for, you must goe to Rome,
For hee shall thither; learne more wit for shame.
Bury your dead—away Grimaldi—leaue'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: Is this a Church-mans voyce? dwels Iustice here?
Flo. Iustice is fledd to Heauen and comes no neerer
Soranzo, was't for him? O Impudence!
Had he the face to speake it, and not blush?
Come, come Donado, there's no helpe in this,
When Cardinals thinke murder's not amisse,
Great men may doe there wills, we must obey,
But Heauen will iudge them for't another day.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Quartus.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter the Fryar, Giouanni, Annabella, Philotis, Soranz, Do∣nado, Florio, Richardetto, Putana and Vasques.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: THese holy rights perform'd, now take your times,
To spend the remnant of the day in Feast;
Such fit repasts are pleasing to the Saint
Who are your guests, though not with mortall eyes
To be beheld; long prosper in this day
You happy Couple, to each others ioy:

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Father, your prayer is heard, the hand of goodnesse
Hath beene a sheild for me against my death;
And more to blesse me, hath enricht my life
With this most precious Iewell; such a prize
As Earth hath not another like to this.
Cheere vp my Loue, and Centlemen, my Friends,
Reioyce with mee in mirth, this day wee'le crowne
With lusty Cups to Annabella's health.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Oh Torture, were the marriage yet vndone,
Ere I'de endure this sight, to see my Loue
Clipt by another, I would dare Confusion,
And stand the horrour of ten thousand deaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: Are you not well Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: Prethee fellow wayte,
I neede not thy officious diligence.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Signior Donado, come you must forget
Your late mishaps, and drowne your cares in wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Reach me that weighty bowle,
Here brother Giouanni, here's to you,
Your turne comes next, though now a Batchelour,
Here's to your sisters happinesse and mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: I cannot drinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Gio.
SP.L: 'Twill indeede offend me

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.L: Pray, doe not vrge him if hee be not willing.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: How now, what noyse is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Vas.
SP.P: O sir, I had forgot to tell you; certaine youg Maidens of Parma in honour to Madam Annabella's marriage, haue sent their loues to her in a Masque, for which they humbly craue your patience and silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.P: Wee are much bound to them, so much the more as it comes vnexpected; guide them in.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Hippolita and Ladies in white Roabes with Garlands of Willowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Soran.
SP.L: Thanks louely Virgins, now might wee but know
To whom wee haue beene beholding for this loue,
Wee shall acknowledge it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Yes, you shall know,
What thinke you now?
Omnes Hippolita?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: 'Tis shee,
Bee not amaz'd; nor blush young louely Bride,
